newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore HSFO traders to raise bids with crude.
newsitem.headline: Singapore HSFO traders to raise bids with crude.

text.p: High sulphur fuel oil buyers were expected to raise bids on Friday in line with crude gains overnight although fundamentals remained unchanged, traders said on Friday.
"With the crude coming up, trader buying will take the opportunity to push up levels," said a Japanese trader.
Traders expected 180 cst cargo prices to rise to $103/$105 a tonne. Prices of 180-cst supplies lifting in September were bid/asked at $102.50/$104 on Thursday.
Singapore paper for September book-out was firmer with bids at $103.50, compared to bids/offers on late Thursday at $102.50/$102.75.
"There is not much change in fundamentals," said a Singapore trader. "Demand is not so great but on the other hand not so much oil is coming from the MidEast."
Traders said Chinese bids were heard but at low levels of $109/$110 a tonne cost-and-freight South China for September delivery.
"I am not keen at all to offer at these levels," said a trader. "It is much easier for South Korean cargoes to work at those prices."
Traders also said high viscosity Venezuelan cargoes have not emerged in Asia and have stayed in the stronger western market since July which should help to prop up levels.
